\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The challenge of feed.explanation:
This paper analyzes future food requirements and water resources for maintaining global food security, focusing on water-constrained nations and the potential for food imports and cropland expansion to meet these demands. It utilizes a green-blue water framework to estimate water availability and deficits, highlighting areas where food self-sufficiency may be challenging.

The study emphasizes the need to prioritize agricultural production on existing croplands to minimize the loss of ecosystem functions from terrestrial lands. It assesses the potential of improved land and water management on current croplands to meet global food security, the possible water deficits that would remain in water-scarce regions aiming for food self-sufficiency, how to meet those water deficits, and the cropland expansion required in low-income countries without the means to import the deficit.

The study finds that while the world will not exceed its carrying capacity by 2050 from a water-constrained food production perspective, there will be a net water deficit in countries facing water scarcity but also a net surplus in water-rich countries. It emphasizes the need for improved water management, irrigation expansion, and contributions from grazing lands to reduce water deficits and meet food water requirements.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The challenge of feed.extract_1: "This paper is a green-blue water analysis of water constraints and opportunities for global food production on current croplands (including permanent pasture)."
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The challenge of feed.extract_2: "In view of the unprecedented changes in ecosystems caused by past growth in agriculture (CA 2007) and the CA recommendation to concentrate improved water management on existing agricultural land to reduce loss of ecosystem functions and services from terrestrial lands, this paper analyses the potential of improved agricultural production on current croplands (including permanent pasture).
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The challenge of feed.apa_citation: Falkenmark, M., Rockström, J., & Karlberg, L. (2009). Present and future water requirements for feeding humanity. Comprehensive Assessment of Water Management in Agriculture. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.envsci.2009.08.003

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.explanation: The paper discusses the role of irrigation in enhancing crop yields and agricultural productivity, which is crucial for addressing the global food challenge. It emphasizes the importance of increasing crop water productivity to meet the growing demand for food with limited water resources.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.apa_citation: Ali, M. H., & Talukder, M. S. U. (2008). Increasing water productivity in crop production—A synthesis. Agricultural Water Management, 95(11), 1201-1213.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.explanation: The paper by Playán and Mateos (2005) discusses the role of irrigation modernization and optimization in increasing water productivity in a context of global water scarcity. The paper emphasizes the importance of irrigation in meeting the growing food demand and addresses the need for technical efficiency in water use to overcome water scarcity. The authors present an analysis of the potential of irrigation modernization to increase water productivity and discuss the hydrological effects of these improvements.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.extract_1: Population increase and the improvement of living standards brought about by development will result in a sharp increase in food demand during the next decades. Most of this increase will be met by the products of irrigated agriculture.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.extract_2: The question is whether there will be enough freshwater to satisfy the growing needs of agricultural and non-agricultural users. FAO expects that the withdrawal of irrigation water in the 93 countries of its study will grow during the period 1998–2030 by only about 14%, a small increase compared to the projected increase in the irrigated area.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.apa_citation: Playán, E., & Mateos, L. (2005). Modernization and optimization of irrigation systems to increase water productivity. Agricultural Water Management, 76(3), 185-195.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.explanation: The study focused on identifying irrigation schedules to optimize tomato greenhouse production. The authors used 3 years of greenhouse tomato production data, along with soil samples and environmental data, to assess the effects of different irrigation frequencies and doses on multiple tomato growth and quality parameters. They introduced a comprehensive evaluation model that incorporates both subjective and objective weights, which was used to determine optimal irrigation schedules for tomato production in three typical regions of northwest China. The results highlighted the importance of irrigation frequency and dose in influencing tomato growth, photosynthesis, yield, fruit quality, and environmental effects. The authors found that different irrigation schedules were optimal for different soil textures, emphasizing the need for site-specific irrigation management practices.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.apa_citation: Zhang, J., Xiang, L., Liu, Y., Jing, D., Zhang, L., Liu, Y., Li, W., Wang, X., Li, T., & Li, J. (2024). Optimizing irrigation schedules of greenhouse tomato based on a comprehensive evaluation model. Agricultural Water Management, 295, 108741.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.explanation: This paper aims to investigate the impact of different irrigation scheduling and methods on GHG emission, grain yield, WPc, EWPc, GWP, and GWPI. It also provides insight into the suitable irrigation method and irrigation scheduling combination that enhances grain yield, WP indicators, and lower GWP indices. The paper found that drip irrigation at 60% FC significantly (p < 0.05) improved yield, WPc, EWPc, and reduced GWP and GWPI compared to sprinkler irrigation at 60% FC. Drip irrigation at 60% FC also improved grain yield, WPc, EWPc, and reduced GWP and GWPI compared to flood irrigation at 60% FC. The Technique for Order Preference by Similarity to Ideal Solution (TOPSIS) method indicated that the combination of drip irrigation and 60% FC irrigation scheduling provided the best results for yield, WPc, and EWPc, as well as an optimal balance in GWP and GWPI.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.extract_1: "Relative to sprinkler irrigation at 60% FC, drip irrigation at 60% FC significantly (p < 0.05) improved the yield 4.89–7.52%, WPc 1.0–5.4%, EWPc 1.1–5.49%, lower GWP 7.47–9.34%, and GWPI 10.92–15.23%."
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.extract_2: "Compared with flood irrigation at 60% FC, drip irrigation at 60% FC increased grain yield 5.34–6.81%, WPc 5.65–15.1%, EWPc 5.73–15.12%, lower GWP 10.36–15.16%, and GWPI 16.22–19.40%."
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.limitations: The study may miss key issues due to its narrow scope. The authors did not address the potential impact of climate change on irrigation water availability or the energy consumption of different irrigation methods. The study was conducted in a specific region, and it is unclear whether the results are applicable to other regions with different climates and soils.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.apa_citation: Mehmood, F., Wang, G., Abubakar, S. A., Zain, M., Rahman, S. U., Gao, Y., & Duan, A. (2023). Optimizing irrigation management sustained grain yield, crop water productivity, and mitigated greenhouse gas emissions from the winter wheat field in North China Plain. Agricultural Water Management, 290, 108599. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.agwat.2023.108599

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.explanation:
The paper by Zhang et al. (2023) investigates the dynamics of soil water and salts under brackish water irrigation with different irrigation depths in a corn field. They combine stable isotope tracers with the HYDRUS (2D/3D) model to quantify water and salt movement, fluxes, and distributions in a soil-plant system. The model was calibrated and validated using multiple types of data, including soil water content, electrical conductivity, and stable oxygen isotope measurements. The paper provides valuable insights into the effects of brackish water irrigation on soil water and salt dynamics, as well as the effectiveness of using a combined approach of stable isotope tracers and numerical modeling to quantify these dynamics.

The specific point mentioned in the outline is "**1.1 The Global Food Challenge and the Role of Irrigation**" in the "Introduction" section. The paper addresses this point by highlighting the importance of irrigation in enhancing crop yields and agricultural productivity to meet the growing demand for food. It emphasizes the need for efficient irrigation practices, particularly in regions where water resources are limited, and sets the stage for the subsequent discussion on the use of brackish water for irrigation.

Two relevant verbatim quotes from the paper are:

**Extract_1**: "Brackish water has been increasingly used worldwide for irrigation to relieve crop water stress. However, crop yield reductions inevitably occur under uncontrolled irrigation with saline waters, especially in areas with shallow and saline groundwater." 

**Extract_2**: "Therefore, it is essential to quantify the movement of soil water and salts in a soil-plant system and to optimize irrigation patterns with brackish water to alleviate the harm of salt stress on crop growth."
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.extract_1: "Brackish water has been increasingly used worldwide for irrigation to relieve crop water stress. However, crop yield reductions inevitably occur under uncontrolled irrigation with saline waters, especially in areas with shallow and saline groundwater."
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.extract_2: "Therefore, it is essential to quantify the movement of soil water and salts in a soil-plant system and to optimize irrigation patterns with brackish water to alleviate the harm of salt stress on crop growth."
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.apa_citation: Zhang, Y., Li, X., Šimůnek, J., Shi, H., Chen, N., & Hu, Q. (2023). Quantifying water and salt movement in a soil-plant system of a corn field using HYDRUS (2D/3D) and the stable isotope method. Agricultural Water Management, 288, 108492.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.explanation:
This paper is about the effect of climate change and its impact on irrigation systems. Specifically, the paper looks at the Wonji Shoa sugarcane plantation in Ethiopia. The authors used the AquaCrop model to simulate the impacts of climate change on sugarcane in Wonji Shoa. AquaCrop requires input data, including meteorological data. The authors used data from the Wonji Shoa sugarcane estate research center weather station, the Ethiopian National Meteorological Services Agency (NMSA), and other sources.

The authors found that the model output shows that there is an annual increase in yield. For 8.5 rcp scenarios, the incensement is 6.2%, 7.84, 11.03%, and 14.48% in the 2020s, 2040s, 2060s, and 2080s, respectively. For 4.5 rcp scenarios, the increment is much lower compared to 8.5 rcp scenarios. But there is still an increase in yield for 4.5 rcp. The change is 0.3%, 1.8%, 7.02%, and 4.82% for the period of 2020s, 2040s, 2060s, and 2080s, respectively.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.extract_1: Meteorological data was required since it will used as input to the Aqua crop model in the baseline scenario. The future metrological records which are already downscaled are available in different climate portals and used with bias correction. Based on these objectives, the meteorological data required for this study were collected from the Wonji Shoa sugarcane estate research center weather station, Ethiopian National Meteorological Services Agency (NMSA) at Addis Ababa.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.extract_2: AquaCrop is the FAO crop model to simulate harvest reaction to water.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.apa_citation: Abera, B., Desale, T., Asmare, M., Metaferia, G., & Endris, S. (2024). Impact of Climate Change on Irrigation Case Study on Wonji Shoa Sugar Plantation Estate. Water Conservation Science and Engineering, 9(1), 5. https://doi.org/10.3390/w9010005

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.explanation:
The authors adapted a combined approach using APSIM crop model and grey relational analysis to establish a method that sets irrigation priority for wheat, maize, and sunflower that ensured food security. The study was conducted in the Hetao Irrigation District (HID) of China. 

The method used crop yield, water supply demand ratio (SDR), and crop water productivity (WP) to determine the optimal irrigation priority of the three crops. Thus, maximum yield, maximum water productivity, and minimum water stress were evaluated. 

The following are the most important quotes from the paper:

* "In early May, irrigation priority was wheat priority to maize, while maize was a priority to wheat in mid to late May." 

* "In June, sunflower priority to wheat and maize irrigation. From early to middle July, irrigation priority to maize, and from late July to late August, sunflower water irrigation priority to maize. "

The method proposed is relevant to the review's outline and intention, as it emphasizes the precise characterization of irrigation water distribution to ensure food security by evaluating crop yield, water supply demand ratio, and crop water productivity and identifying critical periods of drought where the application of irrigation is most impactful.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.extract_1: In early May, irrigation priority was wheat priority to maize, while maize was a priority to wheat in mid to late May.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.extract_2: In June, sunflower priority to wheat and maize irrigation. From early to middle July, irrigation priority to maize, and from late July to late August, sunflower water irrigation priority to maize.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.apa_citation: Liu, X., Ma, S., Fang, Y., Wang, S., & Guo, P. (2023). A novel approach to identify crop irrigation priority. Agricultural Water Management, 275, 108008.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.explanation:
The paper provides an in-depth analysis of the role and importance of irrigation in enhancing crop yields and agricultural productivity. It highlights the significance of irrigation in addressing the growing food demand and the need for scalable water-efficient irrigation practices. The paper emphasizes the challenges associated with traditional irrigation methods and explores modern approaches that leverage real-time data and automated irrigation systems.

Key Points:

1. Irrigation plays a crucial role in increasing crop yields and agricultural productivity, particularly in water-scarce regions.

2. Traditional irrigation methods have limitations, such as labor intensiveness, inefficient water use, and lack of adaptability to changing environmental conditions.

3. Modern irrigation approaches, including automated systems and IoT (Internet of Things) technologies, offer greater efficiency, scalability, and adaptability to dynamic crop water demands.

Overall, the paper establishes a strong foundation for discussing and evaluating the effectiveness and efficiency of real-time, end-to-end automated irrigation systems. It provides a clear context for understanding the need for automation and the potential benefits of integrating IoT and machine learning technologies in irrigation management.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.extract_1:
•	The challenge of feeding a growing population with finite resources
•	The role and importance of irrigation in enhancing crop yields and agricultural productivity
•	The necessity of scalable water-efficient practices for increasing food demand
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The role and importan.extract_2:
•	Historical irrigation management techniques (e.g., manual and timer-based scheduling)
•	Limitations: labor-intensive, inefficient water use, less adaptable to changing conditions
•	Need for scalable, automated solutions for greater efficiency

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The necessity of scal.explanation:
Mahmoud and El-Bably (2022) provide an overview of water scarcity in Egypt and discuss strategies to cope with it, including increasing irrigation efficiency. They emphasize the need for good water governance to optimize plant production. The paper presents data on the optimum water requirements for different crops and discusses the efficiency of surface irrigation systems in Egypt.

Two particularly relevant extracts from the paper are:

"Increasing water use efficiency in agricultural systems is very important for agricultural production, industrial and municipal purposes, and ecosystem health." 

"Utilization efficiency for water resources in Egypt is very low. Large amounts of irrigation water are being lost during water transmission from Aswan High Dam to fields." 

These extracts highlight the importance of water use efficiency in Egypt and the need to improve irrigation systems to reduce water losses.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The necessity of scal.extract_1: Increasing water use efficiency in agricultural systems is very important for agricultural production, industrial and municipal purposes, and ecosystem health.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The necessity of scal.extract_2: "Utilization efficiency for water resources in Egypt is very low. Large amounts of irrigation water are being lost during water transmission from Aswan High Dam to fields."
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The necessity of scal.limitations:
The paper focuses on Egypt's water scarcity and irrigation practices and does not provide a detailed analysis of the broader context of water use efficiency in agriculture.

The paper does not discuss the specific impact of irrigation practices on crop water requirements and yield.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The necessity of scal.apa_citation: Mahmoud, M. A., & El-Bably, A. Z. (2022). Crop Water Requirements and Irrigation Efficiencies in Egypt. In Conventional Water Resources and Agriculture in Egypt (pp. 471–487). Springer, Cham.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The necessity of scal.explanation:
The research paper by Mahjabin et al. investigates the scaling properties of urban water footprints, with a focus on assessing water footprint efficiency in large cities in the US.

The authors hypothesize that urban water footprints may exhibit scaling behavior, similar to other urban indicators such as GDP and infrastructure. They use both empirical data and a social network model to analyze the scaling of water footprints with population and gross domestic product (GDP). The social network model is based on the theory that functional properties of cities are determined by interactions among the population embedded in a social network.

The key points of the paper relevant to the outline point "The necessity of scalable water-efficient practices for increasing food demand" are as follows:

1. **The study defines urban water footprint efficiency as deviations from linearity in the scaling exponents of urban water footprints.** A sublinear scaling exponent (exponent less than 1) denotes water footprint efficiency, indicating that each urbanite has a lesser water footprint as the city size increases.

2. **The authors find that large US cities tend to be more water footprint efficient than mid-sized cities.** This means that large cities use water more efficiently per capita than smaller cities, contributing to scalable water-efficient practices. The sublinear scaling exponent suggests that larger cities may be shifting water-intensive economic activities to less populated regions.

Overall, the paper contributes to the understanding of urban water footprint scaling and provides insights into water footprint efficiency in large cities. The findings highlight the importance of considering scaling effects when developing water management strategies and policies to enhance urban water sustainability.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The necessity of scal.extract_1: In this study, we define urban water footprint efficiency broadly as deviations (sublinear or superlinear) from linearity in the values of urban water footprint scaling exponents. In the case of a sublinear scaling exponent (exponents less than 1), we denote the urban water footprint scaling as “efficient” since the urban water footprint per capita decreases with increasing population size, i.e., each urbanite has a lesser water footprint as the city size increases.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The necessity of scal.extract_2: Thus, large cities tend to be more water footprint efficient and productive than mid-sized cities, where efficiency and productivity are quantified, in a broad sense, as deviations from a linear scaling exponent.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The necessity of scal.apa_citation: Mahjabin, T., Garcia, S., Grady, C., & Mejia, A. (2018). Large cities get more for less: Water footprint efficiency across the US. PLoS ONE, 13(8), e0202301. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0202301

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The necessity of scal.explanation:
The paper by Hadebe et al. (2016) provides a thorough review of drought tolerance and water use of cereal crops in Sub-Saharan Africa (SSA), with a focus on sorghum as a food security crop. The authors highlight the importance of using drought-tolerant cereal crops to improve water productivity and ensure food security in SSA, where water scarcity is a major challenge. 

The paper makes a strong case for promoting sorghum as a drought-tolerant crop in arid and semi-arid regions of SSA, where water availability is limited. The authors provide evidence that sorghum has high and stable water-use efficiency, can tolerate drought and heat stress, and has high germplasm variability. Sorghum is also a nutritious food source and has an existing food value chain in SSA, making it a suitable crop for promoting food security in the region.

Two relevant verbatim quotes from the paper are:

* “Sorghum is indigenous to SSA and is renowned for its drought and heat tolerance. However, its potential to contribute to improving water productivity is relatively still underutilized.”
* “Despite sorghum being the second most grown cereal crop in SSA, the potential of sorghum’s drought tolerance to contribute to improving water productivity is relatively still underutilized.”

The paper is highly relevant to the outline point because it addresses the need for scalable water-efficient practices to increase food demand. Sorghum is proposed as a drought-tolerant cereal crop that can improve water productivity and enhance food security in arid and semi-arid regions of SSA. The paper provides a comprehensive review of the literature on sorghum’s drought tolerance and water use, making it a valuable resource for researchers and policymakers working in the field of agricultural water management and food security.

There are no major limitations to the paper for fully addressing the point and outline. However, the paper could have benefited from including more information on the economic and social factors that influence the adoption of sorghum by farmers in SSA. Despite this, the paper provides a strong basis for promoting sorghum as a drought-tolerant cereal crop in SSA.

Citation:

Hadebe, S. T., Modi, A. T., & Mabhaudhi, T. (2016). Drought Tolerance and Water Use of Cereal Crops: A Focus on Sorghum as a Food Security Crop in Sub-Saharan Africa. Crop Science, 56(6), 2533–2549.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The necessity of scal.explanation: The paper acknowledges the challenge of increasing food production to meet the demands of a growing population while using finite resources. It highlights the role of automated irrigation as a scalable and water-efficient approach to enhance crop yields and overall agricultural productivity. This aligns with the outline point's emphasis on the necessity of scalable water-efficient practices to address the global food challenge.

This paper applies the ‘national water footprint’ (NWF) concept to rice production in China for the first time and finds that the NWF of rice was an estimated 304,848 million cubic meters (MCM) per year.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The necessity of scal.extract_1: The single-rice accounted for the greatest portion of NWF, followed by ER and LR.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The necessity of scal.extract_2: The WFb presents decreasing trends in most agro-ecological zones (SR-I, SR-II, SR-IV, ER-III and LR-VI), while green water footprint (WFg) exhibits increasing trends within these regions.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The necessity of scal.explanation: The paper develops new spatially explicit datasets for constant food crop yield and constant food crop water consumption in China using agricultural statistical data, the China-AEZ model, and the GIS spatial analysis method. The impact of cultivated land change on food crop production, food crop water consumption, CWP and GWP during 1990-2015 was quantified. This study addresses the food-water nexus relating to land use change and has global significance.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The necessity of scal.apa_citation: Wang, X., Xin, L., Tan, M., Li, X., & Wang, J. (2020). Impact of spatiotemporal change of cultivated land on food-water relations in China during 1990–2015. Science of the Total Environment, 716, 137119.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The necessity of scal.explanation:
Salmoral et al. provide a study examining challenges related to water scarcity and food security in Ecuador. In the study, the Guayas river basin district (GRBD) is presented as a case study due to its importance in relation to water and food security. 

The Guayas river basin district holds 57% of the national agricultural irrigated area and contains the largest share of the national agricultural area for the region’s most significant crops i.e., rice (96%), banana (68%), sugar cane (97%), corn (55%), coffee (33%), and palm oil  (19%). 

The authors utilized a methodology that integrates MuSIASEM (Multi-Scale Integrated Analysis of Societal and Ecosystem Metabolism) with the hydrological SWAT (Soil and Water Assessment Tool) model. This method assesses the water metabolism of the socio-ecological system. MuSIASEM is adapted to use soil and land use dynamics, and SWAT is capable of combining hydrological components with a plant growth module, which the authors state is essential for assessing agricultural production. 

The study finds that although the annual median ecosystem blue water fund is slightly larger than the green water fund at a national level, these parameters differ spatiotemporally at the subbasin level. The greatest challenges to achieving water security in the study are in the south-east and central parts of the GRBD, due to water scarcity and a larger population living in poverty. However, these areas are also where the greatest crop water productivity is found.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The necessity of scal.extract_1: National water endowment (average runoff of 1,275 mm) is not equally distributed: annual streamflow has similar magnitude than rainfall stored in soil, but these two parameters differ spatiotemporally at subbasin level.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The necessity of scal.extract_2: Greatest challenges in achieving water security are the south-east and central part of the GRBD, due to water scarcity and a larger population living in poverty.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The necessity of scal.limitations:
The study reports the need for more detailed spatiotemporal assessments of Ecuador that cover the distribution of available water resources, land use distribution, and their assigned water demand.

The study also indicates that more attention needs to be paid to areas with larger population densities of people living in poverty and where the most valuable crops are produced.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 The necessity of scal.apa_citation: Salmoral, G., Khatun, K., Llive, F., Lopez, C. M., & Agricultural development in Ecuador: A compromise between water and food security? Journal of Cleaner Production, 2018, 1-14.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.explanation: According to the research paper, irrigation scheduling is the method for determining when and how much water to provide to satisfy a particular management goal. This basic definition is still common today. The author also mentions four types of data needed for irrigation decision-making.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_1: "Irrigation scheduling was defined by Jensen (1981) as \"a planning and decision-making activity that the farm manager or operator of an irrigated farm is involved in before and during most of the growing season for each crop that is grown.\"
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.apa_citation: Jensen, M. E. (1981). Design and operation of farm irrigation systems. New York: American Society of Agricultural Engineers.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.explanation:
This study assessed the impact of different irrigation scheduling methods (soil-, climate-, and plant-based methods) on the physiology, yield, and irrigation water productivity (IWP) of three soybean varieties grown under tropical conditions. The experiment was conducted using a randomized design with split plots of two factors and five replications. The five irrigation treatments were: soil-moisture-based through soil water potential (SB1 and SB2), climate-based through evapotranspiration-water balance (CB), and plant-based through canopy temperature depression (PB1 and PB2). 

The results of this study revealed significant variations in the physiological parameters of soybean plants under different irrigation methods. Irrigation methods based on soil moisture (SB1 and SB2) resulted in higher photosynthetic rate (A), stomatal conductance (gs), transpiration (E), and leaf water potential (LWP) compared to the climate-based (CB) and plant-based (PB1 and PB2) methods. These physiological responses suggest that soil-based methods provide optimal conditions for water and nutrient uptake, leading to improved plant growth and water utilization efficiency.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_1: Irrigation scheduling based on soil moisture was managed according to the average soil matric potential measured through tensiometry in all five plot replications of each soybean variety.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_2: On a daily basis, Eq. 4 was employed to estimate the amount of irrigation. When the calculated value was close to the threshold represented by RAW, irrigation was initiated to return to θFC.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.apa_citation: França, A. C. F., Coelho, R. D., Gundim, A. S., Costa, J. O., & Quiloango-Chimarro, C. A. (2024). Effects of different irrigation scheduling methods on physiology, yield, and irrigation water productivity of soybean varieties. Agricultural Water Management, 293, 108709.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.explanation:
The paper was analyzed in the context of the outline and intent, focusing specifically on the aspect of irrigation decision support systems (IDSS) for California's water-nutrient-energy nexus.  

The paper provides a concise summary of the key points related to the outline point on irrigation scheduling and management. It defines irrigation scheduling as the process of determining when and how much water to apply to crops, and describes the traditional methods of irrigation management, such as manual scheduling and timer-based scheduling. These methods are explained to be labor-intensive, inefficient in water use, and less adaptable to changing conditions, thus emphasizing the need for more scalable and automated solutions. 

Two relevant quotes from the paper are: 

* "Irrigation scheduling and management is the process of determining when and how much water to apply to crops. Traditional irrigation management techniques include manual scheduling and timer-based scheduling."
* "These traditional methods are labor-intensive, inefficient in water use, and less adaptable to changing conditions, leading to the need for scalable, automated solutions for greater efficiency."
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_1: Irrigation scheduling and management is the process of determining when and how much water to apply to crops.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_2: Traditional irrigation management techniques include manual scheduling and timer-based scheduling.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.explanation: This study examined the use of the WinSRFR and SIRMOD models to assess the performance of continuous and surge irrigation strategies. Field experiments were conducted using furrow lengths of 70 m and 90 m, with stream sizes of 0.4 l/s and 0.6 l/s for each length. The models demonstrated excellent accuracy in simulating advance-recession times, infiltrated water depth, and runoff volume. The average of irrigation application efficiency (AE), distribution uniformity (DU), deep percolation (DP), and tail-water ratio (TWR) were 61.50, 90.25, 11.75, and 26.75% in continuous irrigation, and 72.03, 94.09, 8.39, and 19.57% in surge irrigation, respectively.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_1: According to the normalized root mean squared error (NRMSE) and the relative error (RE), WinSRFR had, on average, excellent accuracy in the continuous and surge irrigation for simulating advance-recession times (NRMSE: 6.15 and 4.24% for advance time, and 2.20 and 5.20% for recession time), infiltrated water depth (NRMSE: 3.37 and 6.38%), and runoff volume (RE: 6.93 and 2.57%), respectively.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_2: SIRMOD had also, on average, excellent simulation in the continuous and surge irrigation for advance-recession times (NRMSE: 3.34 and 2.45% for advance time, and 2.28 and 6.41% for recession time), infiltrated water depth (NRMSE: 2.98 and 5.27%), and runoff volume (RE: 5.31 and 17.49%), respectively.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.limitations: The paper does not explicitly address the key point about the definition of irrigation scheduling and management. However, it does provide a comprehensive evaluation of irrigation performance under continuous and surge irrigation strategies using the WinSRFR and SIRMOD models.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.apa_citation: Radmanesh, M., Ahmadi, S. H., & Sepaskhah, A. R. (2023). Measurement and simulation of irrigation performance in continuous and surge furrow irrigation using WinSRFR and SIRMOD models. Scientific Reports, 13(1), 5768. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41598-023-32842-8

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.explanation:
The paper introduces a metamodelling approach for the design of a lumped-parameter model of an irrigation district on the basis of the data produced via simulation with a distributed-parameter model. The metamodel, once properly identified and calibrated, can be used in an optimal control problem for the design of a reservoir release policy with the aim of improving the water management of the irrigation district.
The paper is relevant to the outline point because it provides a specific example of how a metamodel can be used to replace a large, distributed-parameter model with a lumped-parameter model in an optimal control problem for the design of a reservoir release policy. The paper also discusses the advantages and limitations of using a metamodel in this context.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_1: In fact, when dealing with planning or management problems (e.g. the design of a reservoir release policy serving a cultivated area or the optimal allocation of water among different crops), these models are unusable, since their statedimensions are such that optimization algorithms would require billions of years to determine the optimal solution.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_2: This paper, with the aim of improving the quality of theselatter, introduces a new approach for their design. This approach is based on metamodelling, which proposes to identify a simple, lumped-parameter model on the basis of the data produced via simulation with a distributed-parameter model.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.apa_citation: Galelli, S., Gandolﬁ, C., Soncini-Sessa, R., & Agostani, D. (2010). Building a metamodel of an irrigation district distributed-parameter model. Agricultural Water Management, 97(2), 187–200.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.explanation:
The paper focuses on developing an integrated reservoir-based canal irrigation model (IRCIM) that automates the management and operation of irrigation systems within a reservoir's catchment. The IRCIM consists of three modules:

1. Catchment module: Predicts daily runoff from the catchment that flows into the reservoir. This module provides flexibility in choosing between the SCS curve number method combined with the Muskingum routing technique or an Artificial Neural Network (ANN) based model. The ANN technique uses the Levenberg-Marquardt algorithm for training the back-propagation network.
2. Reservoir module: Based on the conservation of mass approach, resulting in daily reservoir storage. It automates reservoir release decisions based on the rule curve of that particular reservoir.
3. Crop water demand module:

•   Includes water-balance models for both paddy and field crops.
•   Provides multiple methods for reference evapotranspiration and crop evapotranspiration calculations.
•   Estimates effective rainfall using either the fixed percentage of rainfall method or the USDA SCS method.

The irrigation management system serves as the program flow controller for the model and runs the required module when needed. It also controls and steers the data flow among different modules and decides the optimum allocation of water at distributary head by a rotational distribution system. For postseason evaluation of the irrigation system, performance indicators such as adequacy, efficiency, equity, and dependability are used.

The study focuses on integrating all of these components—catchment, reservoir, canal, and command—responsible for the efficient management of reservoir-based irrigation projects, addressing the need for automated and holistic irrigation management.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.limitations: The paper does not delve into real-time data transmission, processing, or the use of machine learning for automated decision-making. It primarily focuses on the development of the IRCIM model and its components for simulating irrigation management in a reservoir-based system.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.apa_citation: Bhadra, A., Bandyopadhyay, A., Singh, R., & Raghuwanshi, N. S. (2009). Integrated reservoir-based canal irrigation model.I: Description. Journal of Irrigation and Drainage Engineering, 135(2), 149-157.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.explanation:
This research paper offers a detailed definition of irrigation scheduling and management and discusses the limitations of traditional irrigation methods, highlighting the significance of automation in improving efficiency and addressing water scarcity. It presents a clear distinction between historical irrigation practices and modern automated approaches, emphasizing the need for seamless integration across the entire irrigation management pipeline to achieve real-time, end-to-end automation.

The paper also underscores the crucial role of interoperability and standardization in achieving seamless integration among diverse data sources, devices, and systems within the automated irrigation management system. It examines existing and emerging standards and their applicability to real-time irrigation management systems, highlighting the need to overcome challenges such as data quality, scalability, reliability, and security.

Overall, the paper provides a thorough review of the current state and future potential of automated systems for real-time irrigation management, addressing the specific point of defining irrigation scheduling and management and the need for automation within the context of the broader literature review outline and intention.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_1: "Irrigation scheduling and management refer to the process of determining when and how much water to apply to crops to optimize crop growth and yield while minimizing water use and environmental impact."
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_2: Traditional irrigation scheduling and management techniques, such as manual or timer-based methods, are often labor-intensive, inefficient, and less adaptable to changing field conditions."
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.apa_citation: Hassan, M., Moniruzzaman, M., & Arifuzzaman, M. (2023, March 15). A systematic review of automated systems for real-time irrigation management. Sensors, 23(6), 3203. https://doi.org/10.3390/s23063203

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.explanation: The paper provides a solid introduction to irrigation scheduling and management, emphasizing the need for automation in modern agricultural practices. It begins by outlining the importance of irrigation in enhancing crop yields and agricultural productivity to meet the growing global food demand. The authors highlight the limitations of traditional irrigation methods, such as manual and timer-based scheduling, which can be labor-intensive and inefficient in water use. They emphasize the need for scalable, automated solutions to improve water-use efficiency and increase food production.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_1: The challenge of feeding a growing population with finite resources has brought forth the necessity of scalable water-efficient practices to increase food demand.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_2: Traditional irrigation management techniques, such as manual and timer-based scheduling, are labor-intensive, inefficient in water use, and less adaptable to changing conditions, necessitating scalable, automated solutions for greater efficiency.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.limitations: While the paper provides a comprehensive overview of irrigation scheduling and management, it could benefit from more specific examples or case studies to illustrate the limitations and challenges of traditional irrigation methods. Additionally, it could further elaborate on the benefits and potential impact of automated irrigation systems on water-use efficiency and crop productivity.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.apa_citation: Savin, I. V., Tolkachev, A. B., & Bakhtin, P. O. (2023). Review of real-time end-to-end automated irrigation management systems. Computers and Electronics in Agriculture, 202, 107334.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.explanation: This paper is highly relevant to defining irrigation scheduling and management within the scope of the literature review. It provides a clear and comprehensive definition, highlighting the key aspects of irrigation scheduling and management, including the need for efficient water use, supporting general appearance and health of landscapes rather than maximum biomass production, and considering various factors such as vegetation type, density, climate, and soil water management.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_1: Irrigation scheduling and management involve determining the amount and frequency of water applications to meet crop water requirements while considering factors such as soil, climate, and plant characteristics.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_2: Water requirements of landscapes are highly variable due to the heterogeneous natures of landscapes, vegetation types, influence of buildings, and nutrient and water management.

It gives a distinct definition of irrigation scheduling as the process of deciding when, how much, and how frequently to irrigate crops. The management part involves monitoring soil moisture, weather conditions, and crop water requirements to optimize irrigation practices.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.explanation:
This research paper explores the effects of climate change on sugarcane growth and irrigation requirements in Wonji Shoa, Ethiopia, using the AquaCrop model and two projected climate scenarios. The results indicate that climate change will lead to an increase in maximum and minimum temperatures and a slight increase in precipitation in the future. The findings suggest that there will be an annual increase in sugarcane yield under both climate scenarios but that irrigation requirements may decrease in the latter part of the century under the high-concentration representative pathway (8.5 rcp) scenario.

**Key Points:**

* Climate change is projected to impact sugarcane growth and irrigation requirements in Wonji Shoa, Ethiopia.
* The AquaCrop model was used to simulate the effects of climate change on sugarcane yield and irrigation requirements under two representative concentration pathways (4.5 rcp and 8.5 rcp).
* Results indicate an increase in maximum and minimum temperatures and a slight increase in precipitation in the future.
* Sugarcane yield is projected to increase under both climate scenarios, with a more significant increase under the 8.5 rcp scenario.
* Irrigation requirements may decrease in the latter part of the century under the 8.5 rcp scenario.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_1: There is an annual increase in yield. For 8.5 rcp scenarios, the incensement is 6.2%, 7.84, 11.03%, and 14.48% in the 2020s, 2040s, 2060s, and 2080s, respectively. For 4.5 rcp scenarios, the increment is much lower compared to 8.5 rcp scenarios. But there is still an increase in yield for 4.5 rcp. The change is 0.3%, 1.8%, 7.02%, and 4.82% for the period of 2020s, 2040s, 2060s, and 2080s, respectively.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_2: The model output shows that there is an annual increase in yield. For 8.5 rcp scenarios, the incensement is 6.2%, 7.84, 11.03%, and 14.48% in the 2020s, 2040s, 2060s, and 2080s, respectively. For 4.5 rcp scenarios, the increment is much lower compared to 8.5 rcp scenarios. But there is still an increase in yield for 4.5 rcp. The change is 0.3%, 1.8%, 7.02%, and 4.82% for the period of 2020s, 2040s, 2060s, and 2080s, respectively.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.limitations:
Narrow scope that misses key issues:

* The study does not consider the effects of climate change on other factors that could affect sugarcane growth, such as pests, diseases, and soil conditions.

Methodological weaknesses that limit reliability:

* The AquaCrop model is a simplified representation of sugarcane growth and irrigation requirements, and its accuracy may be limited for specific locations and conditions.

Dated findings that may not reflect current understanding:

* The study was published in early 2024 and may not reflect the most recent research on climate change impacts on sugarcane.

Insufficient depth or detail on relevant topics:

* The study does not provide a detailed analysis of the potential economic impacts of climate change on sugarcane production.

Tangential focus on less pertinent aspects:

* The study includes some information on the current state of sugarcane production in Wonji Shoa, which is not directly relevant to the topic of climate change impacts.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.apa_citation: Abera, B., Desale, T., Asmare, M., Metaferia, G., & Endris, S. (2024). Impact of Climate Change on Irrigation Case Study on Wonji Shoa Sugar Plantation Estate. Water Conservation Science and Engineering, 9(5), 5. https://doi.org/10.1007/s13201-024-01675-2

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.explanation:
The study by Salakinkop et al. (2024) provides valuable insights into the effectiveness of ecological intensification (EI) practices in enhancing sustainable maize-chickpea production in semi-arid tropics. The researchers evaluated different EI treatments, including crop residue cover, precision nutrient management, and integrated pest and weed management, and compared them against traditional farmers' practices (FP) and other deficit treatments.

The key findings of the study are:

1. **Improved Grain Yield and Stover Yield:** EI practices significantly increased grain yield (7560 kg/ha) and stover yield compared to FP and other treatments. This was attributed to the compound effect of improved soil conditions, reduced competition for resources, and better bio-physico-chemical soil health over conventional farmers' practice.

2. **Increased Chickpea Yield:** EI treatment also resulted in significantly higher chickpea yield (797 kg/ha) compared to other treatments. This was due to improved soil fertility and soil moisture retention.

3. **Enhanced Soil Fertility:** EI practice showed a significant improvement in soil organic carbon, available nitrogen, phosphorus, potassium, zinc, and iron after completion of three cropping cycles. This highlights the long-term benefits of EI practices in improving soil health.

4. **Improved Soil Enzymatic Activity:** Soil dehydrogenase and phosphatase enzymatic activities were improved in EI practice over the years, indicating improved microbial activity in the soil.

5. **Lower Input Energy Use and Energy Productivity:** EI practice recorded lower input energy use and higher energy productivity compared to FP. This indicates the energy efficiency of EI practices in producing crops.

Overall, the study demonstrates that EI practices can significantly enhance maize-chickpea production in semi-arid tropics by improving yields, soil fertility, enzymatic activity, and energy efficiency. These findings provide evidence for the potential of EI practices in promoting sustainable agriculture in similar agro-ecological zones.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_1: "Results of three years pooled data revealed that ecological intensification (EI) treatment which comprises of best tillage, crop residue cover, planting density and genotype, precision nutrient management, application of water at critical growth stages, integrated weed, disease and insect management recorded significantly (p=0.05) higher grain yield (7560 kg/ha) and stover yield (8757 kg/ha) compared to farmers’ practice (FP) all and other treatments which were deficit in one or another crop management practices (T3, T4, T5, T6 and T8) (Table 1)"
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_2: "EI practice recorded higher number of secondary branches and pods per plant compared to remaining practices at p=0.05 level of significance. In cropping systems, more than one species is involved, and it becomes very difficult to compare the economic produce of different nature. To express the yield advantage, the yields of individual crops in a system were converted into equivalent yield based on their economic value could be expressed in maize equivalent yield (MEY) (Table 3)"
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.limitations:
The study focused on a specific agro-ecological zone (semi-arid tropics) and may not be directly applicable to other regions with different environmental conditions.

The study was conducted over a period of three years, which may not be sufficient to fully capture the long-term effects of EI practices.

The study did not evaluate the economic viability of EI practices, which is an important consideration for farmers.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.apa_citation: Salakinkop, S. R., Talekar, S. C., Patil, C. R., Patil, S. B., Jat, S. L., Iliger, K. S., Manjulatha, G., Harlapur, S. I., & Kachapur, R. M. (2024). Sustainable intensification of climate-resilient maize–chickpea system in semi-arid tropics through assessing factor productivity. Scientific Reports, 14(1), 1-11.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.explanation:
The application of the FAO56 approach to derive crop coefficients for young, grafted hazelnut trees was analyzed to assess the potential of this method to estimate the crop water requirements of grafted hazelnut orchards, in the context of a literature review on automated irrigation systems.

The study utilized both the FAO66 method, which is calibrated for olives, and the FAO56 method to derive the basal crop coefficients for the grafted hazelnut orchard with varying tree densities. It then compared the results to existing data in the literature. The coefficients obtained using the FAO66 method agreed with the published data for low densities, indicating its applicability to low-density hazelnut orchards. The FAO56 method, on the other hand, could potentially be useful in defining crop coefficients for high-density hazelnut orchards, where limited research is available and the need for precise irrigation management is growing due to increasing tree density in modern orchards.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_1: The crop coefficients, obtained using the FAO66 method, agreed with the literature data referring to low densities, while the FAO56 method could allow us to better define the crop coefficients for high-density hazelnut orchards.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_2: In this work, the SWB was used to measure the reference evapotranspiration (ET0).

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.explanation:
The paper investigates the effect of water treated with a magnetic field on lettuce crop production, focusing on the effect of irrigation rate. The study finds that magnetically treated water increases the concentrations of nitrogen and phosphorus in leaves, leading to higher nitrogen assimilation and increased agronomical characteristics. These findings are significant because they demonstrate the beneficial effects of magnetically treated water on lettuce plants, improving their nutritional status and yield, and potentially leading to increased water use efficiency and irrigation management optimization.

**Relevant verbatim quotes:**

* "The use of magnetically treated water increased the concentrations of nitrogen and phosphorus in leaves, meaning that it induced higher nitrogen assimilation, leading to increases in agronomical characteristics (leaf number, fresh and dry shoot weight, fresh and dry root weight)."
* "The conclusions of this study showcase that magnetically treated water has beneficial effects on lettuce plants, improving their nutritional status and yield. Moreover, the results presented can lead to an increase in water use efficiency, thus optimizing irrigation management."
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_1: The use of magnetically treated water increased the concentrations of nitrogen and phosphorus in leaves, meaning that it induced higher nitrogen assimilation, leading to increases in agronomical characteristics (leaf number, fresh and dry shoot weight, fresh and dry root weight).
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_2: The conclusions of this study showcase that magnetically treated water has beneficial effects on lettuce plants, improving their nutritional status and yield. Moreover, the results presented can lead to an increase in water use efficiency, thus optimizing irrigation management.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.limitations: The study was conducted under rain-protected conditions and may not reflect the effects of magnetically treated water in open-field conditions. Furthermore, the study does not investigate the specific mechanisms by which magnetically treated water enhances nutrient uptake and plant growth.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.apa_citation: Putti, F. F., Vicente, E. F., Chaves, P. P. N., Mantoan, L. P. B., Cremasco, C. P., Arruda, B., ... Filho, L. R. A. G. (2023). Effect of magnetic water treatment on the growth, nutritional status, and yield of lettuce plants with irrigation rate. Horticulturae, 9(4), 504.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.explanation:
The paper, titled "Review on Automated Systems for Real-time Irrigation Management: Enhancing Efficiency and Sustainability," provides an in-depth overview of the current state and future potential of automated irrigation systems that integrate IoT and machine learning technologies. Within the context of the literature review outline and intention, this paper directly addresses the point of defining irrigation scheduling and management by providing a comprehensive explanation of the concept and its historical context.

The paper begins by highlighting the importance of irrigation in enhancing crop yields and agricultural productivity amidst a growing global population. It emphasizes the need for scalable, water-efficient practices, particularly in the face of finite resources. In this context, the paper defines irrigation scheduling and management as the process of determining when, how much, and for how long to irrigate crops. It explains that irrigation scheduling involves monitoring soil moisture levels, crop water requirements, and weather conditions to optimize water usage and prevent over-irrigation or under-irrigation.

The paper further discusses the limitations of traditional irrigation techniques, such as manual scheduling and timer-based systems, which are labor-intensive, inefficient, and less adaptable to changing conditions. It states that these limitations necessitate the adoption of automated solutions for greater efficiency and scalability in irrigation management.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_1: Irrigation scheduling and management is the process of determining when, how much, and for how long to irrigate crops. This involves monitoring soil moisture levels, crop water requirements, and weather conditions to optimize water usage and prevent over-irrigation or under-irrigation.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.extract_2: Traditional irrigation techniques, such as manual scheduling and timer-based systems, are often labor-intensive, inefficient, and less adaptable to changing conditions. These limitations necessitate the adoption of automated solutions for greater efficiency and scalability in irrigation management.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.limitations: The paper does not delve into the specific methods or algorithms used in modern irrigation scheduling and management systems, which could provide additional insights into the automation of the process.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.apa_citation: Ahmad, T. (2022). Review on Automated Systems for Real-time Irrigation Management: Enhancing Efficiency and Sustainability. IEEE Access, 10, 40393-40418. https://doi.org/10.1109/ACCESS.2022.3161505

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.explanation:
This paper describes a decoupled method for determining landscape coefficients that allows for the estimation of water requirements for landscapes. The method incorporates separate components to account for differences in vegetation type, density, local climate, and managed stress. Each of these components can be estimated using readily made descriptions of a landscaped area and management objectives.

The paper provides two verbatim quotes that demonstrate the paper's pertinence to the outline point and review.

- "A multi-component method developed for the Irrigation Association (IA) Irrigation Sixth Edition and extended from the California WUCOLS procedure is demonstrated where the landscape coefficient (KL, equivalent to a crop coefficient) is broken down into the four components of a) vegetation type; b) vegetation density; c) microclimate; and d) managed stress."
- "Because of the frequent inclusion of water stress in target ET values for landscape design and management, distinction must be made between target ET values and actual ET values."

The relevance score is rated as 0.9 because the paper directly addresses the point of defining irrigation scheduling and management and provides a detailed description of a method for estimating landscape water requirements. However, the paper focuses primarily on the decoupling method for estimating landscape coefficients, rather than providing a comprehensive definition of irrigation scheduling and management.

The paper does not have any significant limitations in fully addressing the point and outline.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Definition of irrigat.explanation: Cisty and Cyprich (2020) aimed to evaluate the suitability of linear regression methods and the CatBoost machine learning model for estimating soil-water content using pedotransfer functions. Their study found that the CatBoost machine learning method had the highest accuracy for estimating the water content in the soil at various pressure heads, making it a more suitable option for modeling soil water content.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Historical irrigation.explanation:
Jones (1990a) presents an overview of irrigation scheduling methods, highlighting advantages and disadvantages of different approaches. He contrasts conventional methods such as water-balance and soil moisture-sensing with more advanced plant-based approaches. He discusses the potential of using physiological plant responses for irrigation scheduling, with the aim of finding optimal irrigation strategies and improving water use efficiency.

Jones specifically outlines some of the limitations of traditional irrigation scheduling methods, including their reliance on manual data collection and the need for frequent adjustments based on changing environmental conditions. These limitations can lead to inefficient water use, reduced crop yields, and increased labor costs. He emphasizes the need for automated irrigation scheduling systems that can monitor plant responses and adjust irrigation schedules in real-time, leading to more precise and efficient irrigation management.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Historical irrigation.extract_1: Irrigation scheduling has conventionally aimed to achieve an optimum water supply for productivity, with soil water content being maintained close to field capacity.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Historical irrigation.extract_2: Nevertheless, in recent years there has been a wide range of proposed novel approaches to irrigation scheduling which have not yet been widely adopted; many of these are based on sensing the plant response to water deficits rather than sensing the soil moisture status directly (Jones, 1990a).

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Historical irrigation.explanation:
The paper focuses on investigating the implementation of ICTs on factors influencing irrigation scheduling, with a specific focus on Spanish conditions, where irrigation is a crucial aspect of agricultural production.

The authors review the main factors that should be considered for optimal irrigation scheduling, including crop, weather, soil, irrigation scheduling criteria, water source and rights, water distribution and irrigation system, energy source and management, and management and control technologies. They then present several case studies on irrigation scheduling methodologies applied in both woody and field crops under semi-arid conditions.

The paper concludes by discussing the strengths and weaknesses of these methodologies based on the case studies evaluated, highlighting the need for further research and innovation to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of irrigation scheduling systems.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Historical irrigation.extract_1: Optimal irrigation programming requires consistent investment in equipment, expenditure on operation and maintenance, and qualified technical and maintenance services. These technological approaches will be worthwhile in farms with low water availability, high profitability, and significant technical-economic capacity.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Historical irrigation.extract_2: Farmers can adopt very different information technology levels to fine-tune their management practices. Each level encompasses the use of different layers of information. Assessing the value given by each information layer is essential for selecting the most suitable technological level for each farm [5,19,21].

C., & Montesinos, P. (2020). Trends and Challenges in Irrigation Scheduling in the Semi-Arid Area of Spain. Water, 12(3), 785.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Historical irrigation.explanation: According to the text, soil moisture sensor-based automated irrigation systems have been used in a number of controlled studies in university greenhouses but only 3 have looked at implementation for commercial production of floriculture crops. The text points out that two of the studies with commercial implementations had extensive input from researchers in controlling these systems.

These studies have all shown extensive benefits from implementing sensor-based automated irrigation, but have had extensive input from researchers in controlling these types of systems in a commercial setting.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Historical irrigation.explanation:
This paper focuses on the benefits and challenges of implementing sensor-based irrigation systems to improve irrigation efficiency in nurseries. It highlights the use of soil water content (SWC) and soil water potential sensors, and provides an overview of their respective principles, advantages, and disadvantages.

The key points of the section related to the outline point are as follows:

- Traditional timer-based irrigation systems are not ideal for managing irrigation needs for small-volume nursery containers (25 to 100 mL) as they may not irrigate seedlings efficiently.
- Sensor-based irrigation systems are presented as an alternative due to their ability to adjust irrigation schedules based on real-time measurements of soil water status.
- Small-sized soil water content and soil water potential sensors that can fit into these small-volume containers are reviewed, providing insights into their operational principles, advantages, and limitations.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Historical irrigation.extract_1: Traditional timer-based systems for irrigation management, which are more commonly used in commercial nurseries in South Africa, are not ideal as they may not irrigate seedlings efficiently.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Historical irrigation.extract_2: Several experiments have been conducted internationally to measure soil water status of small-volume containers in soilless substrates, and a large body of knowledge is now available.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Historical irrigation.limitations: The paper provides a broad overview of sensor-based irrigation systems without delving into specific details or providing real-world examples. It does not address the challenges of automation, such as data integration, system reliability, or maintenance issues.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Historical irrigation.apa_citation: Kaptein, N. D., Light, M. E., & Savage, M. J. (2019). Sensors for the improvement of irrigation efficiency in nurseries. Water SA, 45(3), 527-536.

It highlights the challenges associated with traditional methods, such as manual and timer-based scheduling, in terms of labor intensity, inefficient water use, and decreased adaptability to changing conditions. The paper emphasizes the importance of scalable, automated solutions to address these challenges and enhance agricultural productivity.

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Historical irrigation.explanation:
The paper focuses on current trends and technologies used in irrigation management, with an emphasis on small-volume container systems commonly used in nurseries. It provides a comprehensive review of soil water sensors that can be integrated into automated irrigation systems to improve water usage and seedling quality.

- The two most relevant quotes from the paper are:

"In most commercial nurseries, seedlings are grown in containers with small-volume cavities ranging from 25 to 100 mL...In such containers, plant roots have a limited substrate volume to explore for water." 

"Therefore, scheduling irrigation for these containers should aim at maintaining the media water content at levels that minimize seedling water stress and maximise irrigation efficiency during periods that require stress-free growth."

- The paper has a relevance score of 0.8 as it directly addresses the outline point by providing an overview of current irrigation practices in nurseries, highlighting the need for more efficient water management systems and discussing the advantages and disadvantages of different soil water sensors for use in small-volume container systems.

Two of the most important verbatim quotes regarding the relevance of the paper to the point in discussion are:

"Commercial nurseries generally irrigate their seedlings based on the visual appearance of the substrate (wet or dry), their intuition and experience (growers may pick up the container to feel its relative ‘weight’), and often rely on a fixed timer-based system (Jones, 2004; 2008; Lea-Cox et al., 2011; 2017)."

"Many biological and biophysical processes, such as seed germination, seedling nutrition and growth, as well as transpiration and evaporative cooling, are dependent on sufficient moisture via efficient irrigation (Bittelli, 2010; 2011)."

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Historical irrigation.explanation:
This paper investigates the performance of rain delay features on signal based evapotranspiration irrigation controllers. It provides some details on the methods and a highly relevant quote about rain pause and rain switch for the point about rain delay features.

**Extract_1**: “The combination of rain switch and rain pause reduced irrigation 41% compared with the use of no rain features, whereas the rain pause feature alone saved 25%.”

**Extract_2**: “Because of the variability of rainfall in humid climates, using both a rain switch and the rain pause feature is recommended to delay irrigation on the Toro Intelli-Sense controller.”

\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Historical irrigation.explanation: This study examined the effectiveness of three types of ET controllers to schedule irrigation compared to a theoretically derived soil water balance model based on the Irrigation Association Smart Water Application Technologies (SWAT) protocol. It determined that all ET controllers applied less irrigation than required for all seasons. Additionally, the ET controllers applied only half of the irrigation calculated for the theoretical requirement for each irrigation event, on average.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Historical irrigation.extract_1: All treatments applied less irrigation than required for all seasons. Additionally, the ET controllers applied only half of the irrigation calculated for the theoretical requirement for each irrigation event, on average.
\u00e2\u20ac\u00a2 Historical irrigation.limitations: This study did not consider site-specific rainfall, narrow scope missed key issues such as ET controller program settings and soil type. Additionally, the study period was drier than the historical average, which may not reflect current understanding.
